materials.title: The Human Body & Health
materials.content:
## Your Body and Well-being
Knowing the names of body parts is essential for explaining how you feel to a doctor, describing people's appearances, or even following an exercise routine.

### 1. Detailed Body Vocabulary
*   **The Face & Head:** **Forehead**, **Eyes** (and eyebrows), **Nose**, **Mouth** (lips and teeth), **Chin**, and **Ears**.
*   **The Upper Body:** **Neck**, **Shoulders**, **Chest**, **Arms**, **Elbows**, **Wrists**, **Hands**, and **Fingers**.
*   **The Lower Body:** **Hips**, **Legs**, **Thighs**, **Knees**, **Ankles**, **Feet**, and **Toes**.
*   **Internal & Back:** **Heart**, **Stomach**, **Back**, and **Spine**.

### 2. Expressing Health Problems
In English, we describe pain in three main ways:
*   **Suffix '-ache':** Headache, Stomach ache, Backache, Toothache.
*   **Using 'Hurt':** "My **leg** hurts" or "My **eyes** hurt."
*   **Using 'Sore':** "I have a **sore** throat" or "My muscles are **sore**."

### 3. Grammar: Possessives in Health
When talking to a professional, use possessive adjectives (**my, your, his, her**) to be specific:
*   "**Her** ankle is swollen."
*   "Is **your** back feeling better?"
*   "**My** fingers are cold."

--- 

## Practice Conversations

### Sample Conversation 1: At the Pharmacy (2026 Telehealth Follow-up)
> **Pharmacist:** Hello! I see **your** doctor sent a prescription for your **skin**.
> **Customer:** Yes, **my** arms and **neck** are very itchy.
> **Pharmacist:** Use this cream on **your** shoulders and neck twice a day.
> **Customer:** Thank you. Should I put it on **my** face too?
> **Pharmacist:** No, keep it away from **your** eyes and mouth.

### Sample Conversation 2: At the Gym (Yoga Class)
> **Instructor:** Okay everyone, stand straight. Lift **your** arms above **your** head.
> **Student:** Ow! My **right shoulder** hurts when I do that.
> **Instructor:** Don't push too hard. Keep **your** back straight and bend **your** knees slightly.
> **Student:** That feels better. My **back** was very stiff.

### Sample Conversation 3: Describing a Missing Person
> **Police:** Can you describe the man you saw?
> **Witness:** He was tall with very long **legs**. He had short **brown hair**.
> **Police:** Did you see **his** face clearly?
> **Witness:** Yes, he had a small scar on **his** chin and very large **ears**.

### Sample Conversation 4: A Playground Injury
> **Teacher:** What happened, Leo? Why are you crying?
> **Student:** I fell off the swing. My **knee** is bleeding!
> **Teacher:** Let me see. Does **your** foot hurt too?
> **Student:** No, just **my** knee and **my** left hand.

### Sample Conversation 5: Morning Grumpiness
> **A:** You look tired today. Are you okay?
> **B:** Not really. I have a terrible **toothache** on the left side of **my** mouth.
> **A:** You should call **your** dentist. Does it make **your** head hurt too?
> **B:** Yes, I have a **headache** because I couldn't sleep.

--- 

## Grammar Tip: Plural Body Parts
Most body parts follow standard plural rules, but watch out for **Foot**: 
*   One **Foot** → Two **Feet**.
*   One **Tooth** → Ten **Teeth**.
*   One **Hand** → Two **Hands**.
